Authors:
Conrad C. Labandeira, James M. Cook, Simon J. Goodman,
Carlos Lopez-Vaamonde, Niklas Wikstrom, H. Charles J. Godfray
Title:
Fossil-calibrated molecular phylogenies reveal that
leaf-mining moths radiated several million years after their host
plants
Abstract:
Coevolution has been hypothesized as the main driving
force for the remarkable diversity of insect-plant associations. Dating
of insect and plant phylogenies allows us to test coevolutionary
hypotheses and distinguish between the contemporaneous radiation of
interacting lineages versus insect host tracking of previously
diversified plants. Here, we used nuclear DNA to reconstruct a molecular
phylogeny for 100 species of Phyllonorycter leaf-mining moths and 36
outgroup taxa. Ages for nodes in the moth phylogeny were estimated using
a combination of a penalized likelihood method and a Bayesian approach,
which takes into account phylogenetic uncertainty. To convert the
relative ages of the moths into dates, we used an absolute calibration
point from the fossil record. The age estimates of (a selection of) moth
clades were then compared with fossil-based age estimates of their host
plants. Our results show that the principal radiation of Phyllonorycter
leaf-mining moths occurred well after the main radiation of their
host-plants and may represent the dominant associational mode in the
fossil record.
